detaileddescription.para: Offset to _LF_CLOCK that would convert it to epoch time. For CLOCK_REALTIME, this offset is always zero. For CLOCK_MONOTONIC, it is the difference between those clocks at the start of the execution.
Current time in nanoseconds since January 1, 1970 This is not in scope for reactors. This should only ever be accessed while holding the mutex lock.
Physical time at the start of the execution. This should only ever be accessed while holding the mutex lock.
Logical time at the start of execution. This should only ever be accessed while holding the mutex lock.
Global physical clock offset. Initially set according to the RTI's clock in federated programs.
A measure of calculating the drift between the federate's clock and the RTI's clock
A test offset that is applied to the clock. The clock synchronization algorithm must correct for this offset. This offset is especially useful to test clock synchronization on the same machine.
Stores the last reported absolute snapshot of the physical clock.

Records the most recent time reported by the physical clock when accessed by get_physical_time(). This will be an epoch time (number of nanoseconds since Jan. 1, 1970), as reported when you call lf_clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME, ...). This differs from _lf_last_reported_physical_time_ns by _lf_global_physical_clock_offset plus any calculated drift adjustement, which are adjustments made by clock synchronization.

Compare two tags. Return -1 if the first is less than the second, 0 if they are equal, and +1 if the first is greater than the second. A tag is greater than another if its time is greater or if its time is equal and its microstep is greater.
tag1
tag2
-1, 0, or 1 depending on the relation.

Delay a tag by the specified time interval to realize the "after" keyword. If either the time interval or the time field of the tag is NEVER, return the unmodified tag. If the time interval is 0LL, add one to the microstep, leave the time field alone, and return the result. Otherwise, add the interval to the time field of the tag and reset the microstep to 0. If the sum overflows, saturate the time value at FOREVER.
Note that normally it makes no sense to call this with a negative interval (except NEVER), but this is not checked.
Return the elapsed logical time in nanoseconds since the start of execution.
Return the current tag, a logical time, microstep pair.
Return the current logical time in nanoseconds since January 1, 1970.
Return the current microstep.
Return the current physical time in nanoseconds since January 1, 1970, adjusted by the global physical time offset.

Return the physical time of the start of execution in nanoseconds. * On many platforms, this is the number of nanoseconds since January 1, 1970, but it is actually platform dependent. *
A time instant.
Return the elapsed physical time in nanoseconds. This is the time returned by get_physical_time() minus the physical start time as measured by get_physical_time() when the program was started.

Set a fixed offset to the physical clock. After calling this, the value returned by get_physical_time() and get_elpased_physical_time() will have this specified offset added to what it would have returned before the call.

For C++ compatibility, take a volatile tag_t and return a non-volatile variant.
This is an undefined behavior in C and should be used with utmost caution. See Section 6.7.2 of the C99 standard.

sect1.title: DESCRIPTION
sect1.para: Implementation file for tag functions for Lingua Franca programs.
